title: Final project
text:
0.1 Overview
This project explores interpretable machine learning methods to predict the likelihood of heart disease from patient clinical data.
We build and compare five models:
Our primary goal is not only to achieve high predictive accuracy, but also to understand why a model makes certain predictions.

title: 3Â  Model Overview
text:
3.1 Models Overview
We trained five different models on the heart disease prediction dataset:
All models were implemented using the tidymodels framework in R. The dataset was split into 70% training and 30% testing.
Each model includes preprocessing via recipes, and uses cross-validation or default settings depending on the complexity.
Model explanations using LIME are further discussed in the next chapter.
These models are compared in terms of predictive performance and explainability in later sections.

title: 6Â  Conclusion
text:
6.1 Final Summary & Insights
This final section summarizes our findings by comparing model performance, interpretation consistency, and implications for medical trust.

title: 6Â  Conclusion
text:
LIME explanations aligned more closely with simpler models like decision trees.
For more complex models (e.g., neural networks), the LIME feature rankings showed greater variability.
Some features such as Age, ChestPainType, and Cholesterol were consistently important across models and explanations.

title: 6Â  Conclusion
text:
6.2 Limitations

LIME explanations are local and may not reflect the global model behavior.
The comparison is limited to one dataset and a small sample of instances.
Model hyperparameters and preprocessing choices could affect results.

title: 6Â  Conclusion
text:
6.3 Future Directions

Explore other interpretability methods such as SHAP or Anchor explanations.
Apply the same analysis to other medical prediction datasets.
Involve domain experts (e.g., clinicians) to assess explanation usefulness in real-world decision-making.


This project highlights both the potential and the caution needed when interpreting machine learning models, especially in healthcare.

text:
4.6 Global Feature Importance


Code
library(rpart)



Attaching package: 'rpart'


The following object is masked from 'package:dials':

    prune


Code
# Extract variable importance from underlying fitted model
rpart_fit <- extract_fit_parsnip(tree_fit)$fit

vip <- data.frame(
  Feature = names(rpart_fit$variable.importance),
  Importance = as.numeric(rpart_fit$variable.importance)
) %>%
  arrange(desc(Importance)) %>%
  slice_head(n = 5)


# Plot top 5 features
vip %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = fct_reorder(Feature, Importance), y = Importance)) +
  geom_col(fill = "steelblue") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Top 5 Feature Importances (Decision Tree)", x = NULL, y = "Importance")









The top 5 most important features for the decision tree include two Thalassemia categories (Thalassemia_X2 and Thalassemia_X3), followed by the number of major vessels, Oldpeak, and MaxHR. These features drive the majority of the splits in the tree, indicating their strong influence in predicting heart disease.

  summarise(avg_weight = mean(feature_weight)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = fct_reorder(feature_desc, avg_weight), y = avg_weight, fill = avg_weight > 0)) +
  geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +
  coord_flip() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("firebrick", "darkgreen")) +
  labs(title = "Average LIME Contributions (Random Forest)", x = NULL, y = "Avg Feature Weight")













5.1.3 Note on Other Models

SVM and Neural Network were not compatible with lime due to limitations in the package.
Logistic Regression was interpreted using the iml::LocalModel method (see logistic_model.qmd for details).

6.1.4 Conclusion

Models like Decision Tree and Logistic Regression offer strong interpretability and align well with their LIME/IML explanations.
Random Forest balances performance and explainability with moderate stability.
SVM and Neural Network performed reasonably but lacked interpretable support from LIME in our pipeline.
For medical settings, interpretable models with consistent explanations are recommended for building trust and transparency.
